Policy Gradient Algorithms

Apr 8, 2018 by Lilian Weng reinforcement-learning  long-read 

Abstract: In this post, we are going to look deep into policy gradient, why it works, and many new policy gradient algorithms proposed in recent years: vanilla policy gradient, actor-critic, off-policy actor-critic, A3C, A2C, DPG, DDPG, D4PG, MADDPG, TRPO, PPO, ACER, ACTKR, SAC, TD3 & SVPG.

What is Policy Gradient

Policy gradient is an approach to solve reinforcement learning problems. If you haven‚Äôt looked into the field of reinforcement learning, please first read the section ‚ÄúA (Long) Peek into Reinforcement Learning ¬ª Key Concepts‚Äù for the problem definition and key concepts.

Here is a list of notations to help you read through equations in the post easily.

Policy Gradient

The goal of reinforcement learning is to find an optimal behavior strategy for the agent to obtain optimal rewards. The policy gradient methods target at modeling and optimizing the policy directly. The policy is usually modeled with a parameterized function respect to Œ∏Œ∏, œÄŒ∏(a|s)œÄŒ∏(a|s). The value of the reward (objective) function depends on this policy and then various algorithms can be applied to optimize Œ∏Œ∏ for the best reward.

The reward function is defined as:

J(Œ∏)=‚àës‚ààSdœÄ(s)VœÄ(s)=‚àës‚ààSdœÄ(s)‚àëa‚ààAœÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)J(Œ∏)=‚àës‚ààSdœÄ(s)VœÄ(s)=‚àës‚ààSdœÄ(s)‚àëa‚ààAœÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)

where dœÄ(s)dœÄ(s) is the stationary distribution of Markov chain for œÄŒ∏œÄŒ∏ (on-policy state distribution under œÄœÄ). For simplicity, the parameter Œ∏Œ∏ would be omitted for the policy œÄŒ∏œÄŒ∏ when the policy is present in the subscript of other functions; for example, dœÄdœÄ and QœÄQœÄ should be dœÄŒ∏dœÄŒ∏ and QœÄŒ∏QœÄŒ∏ if written in full.

Imagine that you can travel along the Markov chain‚Äôs states forever, and eventually, as the time progresses, the probability of you ending up with one state becomes unchanged ‚Äî this is the stationary probability for œÄŒ∏œÄŒ∏. dœÄ(s)=limt‚Üí‚àûP(st=s|s0,œÄŒ∏)dœÄ(s)=limt‚Üí‚àûP(st=s|s0,œÄŒ∏) is the probability that st=sst=s when starting from s0s0 and following policy œÄŒ∏œÄŒ∏ for t steps. Actually, the existence of the stationary distribution of Markov chain is one main reason for why PageRank algorithm works. If you want to read more, check this.

It is natural to expect policy-based methods are more useful in the continuous space. Because there is an infinite number of actions and (or) states to estimate the values for and hence value-based approaches are way too expensive computationally in the continuous space. For example, in generalized policy iteration, the policy improvement step argmaxa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)arg‚Å°maxa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a) requires a full scan of the action space, suffering from the curse of dimensionality.

Using gradient ascent, we can move Œ∏Œ∏ toward the direction suggested by the gradient ‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏) to find the best Œ∏Œ∏ for œÄŒ∏œÄŒ∏ that produces the highest return.

Policy Gradient Theorem

Computing the gradient ‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏) is tricky because it depends on both the action selection (directly determined by œÄŒ∏œÄŒ∏) and the stationary distribution of states following the target selection behavior (indirectly determined by œÄŒ∏œÄŒ∏). Given that the environment is generally unknown, it is difficult to estimate the effect on the state distribution by a policy update.

Luckily, the policy gradient theorem comes to save the world! Woohoo! It provides a nice reformation of the derivative of the objective function to not involve the derivative of the state distribution dœÄ(.)dœÄ(.) and simplify the gradient computation ‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏) a lot.

‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)=‚àáŒ∏‚àës‚ààSdœÄ(s)‚àëa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àù‚àës‚ààSdœÄ(s)‚àëa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)=‚àáŒ∏‚àës‚ààSdœÄ(s)‚àëa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àù‚àës‚ààSdœÄ(s)‚àëa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)

Proof of Policy Gradient Theorem

This session is pretty dense, as it is the time for us to go through the proof (Sutton & Barto, 2017; Sec. 13.1) and figure out why the policy gradient theorem is correct.

We first start with the derivative of the state value function:

=====‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s)‚àáŒ∏(‚àëa‚ààAœÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a))‚àëa‚ààA(‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)+œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àáŒ∏QœÄ(s,a))‚àëa‚ààA(‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)+œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àáŒ∏‚àës‚Ä≤,rP(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a)(r+VœÄ(s‚Ä≤)))‚àëa‚ààA(‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)+œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àës‚Ä≤,rP(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤))‚àëa‚ààA(‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)+œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àës‚Ä≤P(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤)); Derivative product rule.; Extend QœÄ with future state value.P(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a) or r is not a func of Œ∏; Because P(s‚Ä≤|s,a)=‚àërP(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s)=‚àáŒ∏(‚àëa‚ààAœÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a))=‚àëa‚ààA(‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)+œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àáŒ∏QœÄ(s,a)); Derivative product rule.=‚àëa‚ààA(‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)+œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àáŒ∏‚àës‚Ä≤,rP(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a)(r+VœÄ(s‚Ä≤))); Extend QœÄ with future state value.=‚àëa‚ààA(‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)+œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àës‚Ä≤,rP(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤))P(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a) or r is not a func of Œ∏=‚àëa‚ààA(‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)+œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àës‚Ä≤P(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤)); Because P(s‚Ä≤|s,a)=‚àërP(s‚Ä≤,r|s,a)

Now we have:

‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s)=‚àëa‚ààA(‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)+œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àës‚Ä≤P(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤))‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s)=‚àëa‚ààA(‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)+œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àës‚Ä≤P(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤))

This equation has a nice recursive form (see the red parts!) and the future state value function VœÄ(s‚Ä≤)VœÄ(s‚Ä≤) can be repeated unrolled by following the same equation.

Let‚Äôs consider the following visitation sequence and label the probability of transitioning from state s to state x with policy œÄŒ∏œÄŒ∏ after k step as œÅœÄ(s‚Üíx,k)œÅœÄ(s‚Üíx,k).

s‚àí‚Üí‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àía‚àºœÄŒ∏(.|s)s‚Ä≤‚àí‚Üí‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àía‚àºœÄŒ∏(.|s‚Ä≤)s‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚àí‚Üí‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àí‚àía‚àºœÄŒ∏(.|s‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)‚Ä¶s‚Üía‚àºœÄŒ∏(.|s)s‚Ä≤‚Üía‚àºœÄŒ∏(.|s‚Ä≤)s‚Ä≥‚Üía‚àºœÄŒ∏(.|s‚Ä≥)‚Ä¶
  • When k = 0: œÅœÄ(s‚Üís,k=0)=1œÅœÄ(s‚Üís,k=0)=1.
  • When k = 1, we scan through all possible actions and sum up the transition probabilities to the target state: œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,k=1)=‚àëaœÄŒ∏(a|s)P(s‚Ä≤|s,a)œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,k=1)=‚àëaœÄŒ∏(a|s)P(s‚Ä≤|s,a).
  • Imagine that the goal is to go from state s to x after k+1 steps while following policy œÄŒ∏œÄŒ∏. We can first travel from s to a middle point s‚Äô (any state can be a middle point, s‚Ä≤‚ààSs‚Ä≤‚ààS) after k steps and then go to the final state x during the last step. In this way, we are able to update the visitation probability recursively: œÅœÄ(s‚Üíx,k+1)=‚àës‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,k)œÅœÄ(s‚Ä≤‚Üíx,1)œÅœÄ(s‚Üíx,k+1)=‚àës‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,k)œÅœÄ(s‚Ä≤‚Üíx,1).

Then we go back to unroll the recursive representation of ‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s)! Let œï(s)=‚àëa‚ààA‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)œï(s)=‚àëa‚ààA‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a) to simplify the maths. If we keep on extending ‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(.)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(.) infinitely, it is easy to find out that we can transition from the starting state s to any state after any number of steps in this unrolling process and by summing up all the visitation probabilities, we get ‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s)!

=========‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s)œï(s)+‚àëaœÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àës‚Ä≤P(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤)œï(s)+‚àës‚Ä≤‚àëaœÄŒ∏(a|s)P(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤)œï(s)+‚àës‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,1)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤)œï(s)+‚àës‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,1)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤)œï(s)+‚àës‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,1)[œï(s‚Ä≤)+‚àës‚Ä≤‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Ä≤‚Üís‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,1)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)]œï(s)+‚àës‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,1)œï(s‚Ä≤)+‚àës‚Ä≤‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,2)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤‚Ä≤) ; Consider s‚Ä≤ as the middle point for s‚Üís‚Ä≤‚Ä≤œï(s)+‚àës‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,1)œï(s‚Ä≤)+‚àës‚Ä≤‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,2)œï(s‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)+‚àës‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Ä≤,3)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤‚Ä≤‚Ä≤)‚Ä¶; Repeatedly unrolling the part of ‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(.)‚àëx‚ààS‚àëk=0‚àûœÅœÄ(s‚Üíx,k)œï(x)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s)=œï(s)+‚àëaœÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àës‚Ä≤P(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤)=œï(s)+‚àës‚Ä≤‚àëaœÄŒ∏(a|s)P(s‚Ä≤|s,a)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤)=œï(s)+‚àës‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,1)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤)=œï(s)+‚àës‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,1)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≤)=œï(s)+‚àës‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,1)[œï(s‚Ä≤)+‚àës‚Ä≥œÅœÄ(s‚Ä≤‚Üís‚Ä≥,1)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≥)]=œï(s)+‚àës‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,1)œï(s‚Ä≤)+‚àës‚Ä≥œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≥,2)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä≥) ; Consider s‚Ä≤ as the middle point for s‚Üís‚Ä≥=œï(s)+‚àës‚Ä≤œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,1)œï(s‚Ä≤)+‚àës‚Ä≥œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä≥,2)œï(s‚Ä≥)+‚àës‚Ä¥œÅœÄ(s‚Üís‚Ä¥,3)‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s‚Ä¥)=‚Ä¶; Repeatedly unrolling the part of ‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(.)=‚àëx‚ààS‚àëk=0‚àûœÅœÄ(s‚Üíx,k)œï(x)

The nice rewriting above allows us to exclude the derivative of Q-value function, ‚àáŒ∏QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏QœÄ(s,a). By plugging it into the objective function J(Œ∏)J(Œ∏), we are getting the following:

‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)=‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s0)=‚àës‚àëk=0‚àûœÅœÄ(s0‚Üís,k)œï(s)=‚àësŒ∑(s)œï(s)=(‚àësŒ∑(s))‚àësŒ∑(s)‚àësŒ∑(s)œï(s)‚àù‚àësŒ∑(s)‚àësŒ∑(s)œï(s)=‚àësdœÄ(s)‚àëa‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a); Starting from a random state s0; Let Œ∑(s)=‚àë‚àûk=0œÅœÄ(s0‚Üís,k); Normalize Œ∑(s),s‚ààS to be a probability distribution.‚àësŒ∑(s) is a constantdœÄ(s)=Œ∑(s)‚àësŒ∑(s) is stationary distribution.‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)=‚àáŒ∏VœÄ(s0); Starting from a random state s0=‚àës‚àëk=0‚àûœÅœÄ(s0‚Üís,k)œï(s); Let Œ∑(s)=‚àëk=0‚àûœÅœÄ(s0‚Üís,k)=‚àësŒ∑(s)œï(s)=(‚àësŒ∑(s))‚àësŒ∑(s)‚àësŒ∑(s)œï(s); Normalize Œ∑(s),s‚ààS to be a probability distribution.‚àù‚àësŒ∑(s)‚àësŒ∑(s)œï(s)‚àësŒ∑(s) is a constant=‚àësdœÄ(s)‚àëa‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)dœÄ(s)=Œ∑(s)‚àësŒ∑(s) is stationary distribution.

In the episodic case, the constant of proportionality (‚àësŒ∑(s)‚àësŒ∑(s)) is the average length of an episode; in the continuing case, it is 1 (Sutton & Barto, 2017; Sec. 13.2). The gradient can be further written as:

‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)‚àù‚àës‚ààSdœÄ(s)‚àëa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)=‚àës‚ààSdœÄ(s)‚àëa‚ààAœÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)œÄŒ∏(a|s)=EœÄ[QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏lnœÄŒ∏(a|s)]; Because (lnx)‚Ä≤=1/x‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)‚àù‚àës‚ààSdœÄ(s)‚àëa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)=‚àës‚ààSdœÄ(s)‚àëa‚ààAœÄŒ∏(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)œÄŒ∏(a|s)=EœÄ[QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏ln‚Å°œÄŒ∏(a|s)]; Because (ln‚Å°x)‚Ä≤=1/x

Where EœÄEœÄ refers to Es‚àºdœÄ,a‚àºœÄŒ∏Es‚àºdœÄ,a‚àºœÄŒ∏ when both state and action distributions follow the policy œÄŒ∏œÄŒ∏ (on policy).

The policy gradient theorem lays the theoretical foundation for various policy gradient algorithms. This vanilla policy gradient update has no bias but high variance. Many following algorithms were proposed to reduce the variance while keeping the bias unchanged.

‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)=EœÄ[QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏lnœÄŒ∏(a|s)]‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)=EœÄ[QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏ln‚Å°œÄŒ∏(a|s)]

Here is a nice summary of a general form of policy gradient methods borrowed from the GAE (general advantage estimation) paper (Schulman et al., 2016) and this post thoroughly discussed several components in GAE , highly recommended.

Fig. 1. A general form of policy gradient methods. (Image source: Schulman et al., 2016)

Policy Gradient Algorithms

Tons of policy gradient algorithms have been proposed during recent years and there is no way for me to exhaust them. I‚Äôm introducing some of them that I happened to know and read about.

REINFORCE

REINFORCE (Monte-Carlo policy gradient) relies on an estimated return by Monte-Carlo methods using episode samples to update the policy parameter Œ∏Œ∏. REINFORCE works because the expectation of the sample gradient is equal to the actual gradient:

‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)=EœÄ[QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏lnœÄŒ∏(a|s)]=EœÄ[Gt‚àáŒ∏lnœÄŒ∏(At|St)]; Because QœÄ(St,At)=EœÄ[Gt|St,At]‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)=EœÄ[QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏ln‚Å°œÄŒ∏(a|s)]=EœÄ[Gt‚àáŒ∏ln‚Å°œÄŒ∏(At|St)]; Because QœÄ(St,At)=EœÄ[Gt|St,At]

Therefore we are able to measure GtGt from real sample trajectories and use that to update our policy gradient. It relies on a full trajectory and that‚Äôs why it is a Monte-Carlo method.

The process is pretty straightforward:

  1. Initialize the policy parameter Œ∏Œ∏ at random.
  2. Generate one trajectory on policy œÄŒ∏œÄŒ∏: S1,A1,R2,S2,A2,‚Ä¶,STS1,A1,R2,S2,A2,‚Ä¶,ST.
  3. For t=1, 2, ‚Ä¶ , T:
    1. Estimate the the return GtGt;
    2. Update policy parameters: Œ∏‚ÜêŒ∏+Œ±Œ≥tGt‚àáŒ∏lnœÄŒ∏(At|St)Œ∏‚ÜêŒ∏+Œ±Œ≥tGt‚àáŒ∏ln‚Å°œÄŒ∏(At|St)

A widely used variation of REINFORCE is to subtract a baseline value from the return GtGt to reduce the variance of gradient estimation while keeping the bias unchanged (Remember we always want to do this when possible). For example, a common baseline is to subtract state-value from action-value, and if applied, we would use advantage A(s,a)=Q(s,a)‚àíV(s)A(s,a)=Q(s,a)‚àíV(s) in the gradient ascent update. This post nicely explained why a baseline works for reducing the variance, in addition to a set of fundamentals of policy gradient.

Actor-Critic

Two main components in policy gradient are the policy model and the value function. It makes a lot of sense to learn the value function in addition to the policy, since knowing the value function can assist the policy update, such as by reducing gradient variance in vanilla policy gradients, and that is exactly what the Actor-Critic method does.

Actor-critic methods consist of two models, which may optionally share parameters:

  • Critic updates the value function parameters w and depending on the algorithm it could be action-value Qw(a|s)Qw(a|s) or state-value Vw(s)Vw(s).
  • Actor updates the policy parameters Œ∏Œ∏ for œÄŒ∏(a|s)œÄŒ∏(a|s), in the direction suggested by the critic.

Let‚Äôs see how it works in a simple action-value actor-critic algorithm.

  1. Initialize s,Œ∏,ws,Œ∏,w at random; sample a‚àºœÄŒ∏(a|s)a‚àºœÄŒ∏(a|s).
  2. For t=1‚Ä¶Tt=1‚Ä¶T:
    1. Sample reward rt‚àºR(s,a)rt‚àºR(s,a) and next state s‚Ä≤‚àºP(s‚Ä≤|s,a)s‚Ä≤‚àºP(s‚Ä≤|s,a);
    2. Then sample the next action a‚Ä≤‚àºœÄŒ∏(a‚Ä≤|s‚Ä≤)a‚Ä≤‚àºœÄŒ∏(a‚Ä≤|s‚Ä≤);
    3. Update the policy parameters: Œ∏‚ÜêŒ∏+Œ±Œ∏Qw(s,a)‚àáŒ∏lnœÄŒ∏(a|s)Œ∏‚ÜêŒ∏+Œ±Œ∏Qw(s,a)‚àáŒ∏ln‚Å°œÄŒ∏(a|s);
    4. Compute the correction (TD error) for action-value at time t:
      Œ¥t=rt+Œ≥Qw(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤)‚àíQw(s,a)Œ¥t=rt+Œ≥Qw(s‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤)‚àíQw(s,a)
      and use it to update the parameters of action-value function:
      w‚Üêw+Œ±wŒ¥t‚àáwQw(s,a)w‚Üêw+Œ±wŒ¥t‚àáwQw(s,a)
    5. Update a‚Üêa‚Ä≤a‚Üêa‚Ä≤ and s‚Üês‚Ä≤s‚Üês‚Ä≤.

Two learning rates, Œ±Œ∏Œ±Œ∏ and Œ±wŒ±w, are predefined for policy and value function parameter updates respectively.

Off-Policy Policy Gradient

Both REINFORCE and the vanilla version of actor-critic method are on-policy: training samples are collected according to the target policy ‚Äî the very same policy that we try to optimize for. Off policy methods, however, result in several additional advantages:

  1. The off-policy approach does not require full trajectories and can reuse any past episodes (‚Äúexperience replay‚Äù) for much better sample efficiency.
  2. The sample collection follows a behavior policy different from the target policy, bringing better exploration.

Now let‚Äôs see how off-policy policy gradient is computed. The behavior policy for collecting samples is a known policy (predefined just like a hyperparameter), labelled as Œ≤(a|s)Œ≤(a|s). The objective function sums up the reward over the state distribution defined by this behavior policy:

J(Œ∏)=‚àës‚ààSdŒ≤(s)‚àëa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)œÄŒ∏(a|s)=Es‚àºdŒ≤[‚àëa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)œÄŒ∏(a|s)]J(Œ∏)=‚àës‚ààSdŒ≤(s)‚àëa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)œÄŒ∏(a|s)=Es‚àºdŒ≤[‚àëa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)œÄŒ∏(a|s)]

where dŒ≤(s)dŒ≤(s) is the stationary distribution of the behavior policy Œ≤Œ≤; recall that dŒ≤(s)=limt‚Üí‚àûP(St=s|S0,Œ≤)dŒ≤(s)=limt‚Üí‚àûP(St=s|S0,Œ≤); and QœÄQœÄ is the action-value function estimated with regard to the target policy œÄœÄ (not the behavior policy!).

Given that the training observations are sampled by a‚àºŒ≤(a|s)a‚àºŒ≤(a|s), we can rewrite the gradient as:

‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)=‚àáŒ∏Es‚àºdŒ≤[‚àëa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)œÄŒ∏(a|s)]=Es‚àºdŒ≤[‚àëa‚ààA(QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)+œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àáŒ∏QœÄ(s,a))]‚âà(i)Es‚àºdŒ≤[‚àëa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)]=Es‚àºdŒ≤[‚àëa‚ààAŒ≤(a|s)œÄŒ∏(a|s)Œ≤(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)œÄŒ∏(a|s)]=EŒ≤[œÄŒ∏(a|s)Œ≤(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏lnœÄŒ∏(a|s)]; Derivative product rule.; Ignore the red part: œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àáŒ∏QœÄ(s,a).; The blue part is the importance weight.‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)=‚àáŒ∏Es‚àºdŒ≤[‚àëa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)œÄŒ∏(a|s)]=Es‚àºdŒ≤[‚àëa‚ààA(QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)+œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àáŒ∏QœÄ(s,a))]; Derivative product rule.‚âà(i)Es‚àºdŒ≤[‚àëa‚ààAQœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)]; Ignore the red part: œÄŒ∏(a|s)‚àáŒ∏QœÄ(s,a).=Es‚àºdŒ≤[‚àëa‚ààAŒ≤(a|s)œÄŒ∏(a|s)Œ≤(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏œÄŒ∏(a|s)œÄŒ∏(a|s)]=EŒ≤[œÄŒ∏(a|s)Œ≤(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏ln‚Å°œÄŒ∏(a|s)]; The blue part is the importance weight.

where œÄŒ∏(a|s)Œ≤(a|s)œÄŒ∏(a|s)Œ≤(a|s) is the importance weight. Because QœÄQœÄ is a function of the target policy and thus a function of policy parameter Œ∏Œ∏, we should take the derivative of ‚àáŒ∏QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏QœÄ(s,a) as well according to the product rule. However, it is super hard to compute ‚àáŒ∏QœÄ(s,a)‚àáŒ∏QœÄ(s,a) in reality. Fortunately if we use an approximated gradient with the gradient of Q ignored, we still guarantee the policy improvement and eventually achieve the true local minimum. This is justified in the proof here (Degris, White & Sutton, 2012).

In summary, when applying policy gradient in the off-policy setting, we can simple adjust it with a weighted sum and the weight is the ratio of the target policy to the behavior policy, œÄŒ∏(a|s)Œ≤(a|s)œÄŒ∏(a|s)Œ≤(a|s).

A3C

[paper|code]

Asynchronous Advantage Actor-Critic (Mnih et al., 2016), short for A3C, is a classic policy gradient method with a special focus on parallel training.

In A3C, the critics learn the value function while multiple actors are trained in parallel and get synced with global parameters from time to time. Hence, A3C is designed to work well for parallel training.

Let‚Äôs use the state-value function as an example. The loss function for state value is to minimize the mean squared error, Jv(w)=(Gt‚àíVw(s))2Jv(w)=(Gt‚àíVw(s))2 and gradient descent can be applied to find the optimal w. This state-value function is used as the baseline in the policy gradient update.

Here is the algorithm outline:

  1. We have global parameters, Œ∏Œ∏ and ww; similar thread-specific parameters, Œ∏‚Ä≤Œ∏‚Ä≤ and w‚Ä≤w‚Ä≤.
  2. Initialize the time step t=1t=1
  3. While T‚â§TMAXT‚â§TMAX:
    1. Reset gradient: dŒ∏=0dŒ∏=0 and dw=0dw=0.
    2. Synchronize thread-specific parameters with global ones: Œ∏‚Ä≤=Œ∏Œ∏‚Ä≤=Œ∏ and w‚Ä≤=ww‚Ä≤=w.
    3. tstarttstart = t and sample a starting state stst.
    4. While (stst != TERMINAL) and t‚àítstart‚â§tmaxt‚àítstart‚â§tmax:
      1. Pick the action At‚àºœÄŒ∏‚Ä≤(At|St)At‚àºœÄŒ∏‚Ä≤(At|St) and receive a new reward RtRt and a new state st+1st+1.
      2. Update t=t+1t=t+1 and T=T+1T=T+1
    5. Initialize the variable that holds the return estimation R={0Vw‚Ä≤(st)if st is TERMINALotherwiseR={0if st is TERMINALVw‚Ä≤(st)otherwise
    6. For i=t‚àí1,‚Ä¶,tstarti=t‚àí1,‚Ä¶,tstart:
      1. R‚ÜêŒ≥R+RiR‚ÜêŒ≥R+Ri; here R is a MC measure of GiGi.
      2. Accumulate gradients w.r.t. Œ∏‚Ä≤Œ∏‚Ä≤: dŒ∏‚ÜêdŒ∏+‚àáŒ∏‚Ä≤logœÄŒ∏‚Ä≤(ai|si)(R‚àíVw‚Ä≤(si))dŒ∏‚ÜêdŒ∏+‚àáŒ∏‚Ä≤log‚Å°œÄŒ∏‚Ä≤(ai|si)(R‚àíVw‚Ä≤(si));
        Accumulate gradients w.r.t. w‚Äô: dw‚Üêdw+2(R‚àíVw‚Ä≤(si))‚àáw‚Ä≤(R‚àíVw‚Ä≤(si))dw‚Üêdw+2(R‚àíVw‚Ä≤(si))‚àáw‚Ä≤(R‚àíVw‚Ä≤(si)).
    7. Update asynchronously Œ∏Œ∏ using dŒ∏dŒ∏, and ww using dwdw.

A3C enables the parallelism in multiple agent training. The gradient accumulation step (6.2) can be considered as a parallelized reformation of minibatch-based stochastic gradient update: the values of ww or Œ∏Œ∏ get corrected by a little bit in the direction of each training thread independently.

A2C

[paper|code]

A2C is a synchronous, deterministic version of A3C; that‚Äôs why it is named as ‚ÄúA2C‚Äù with the first ‚ÄúA‚Äù (‚Äúasynchronous‚Äù) removed. In A3C each agent talks to the global parameters independently, so it is possible sometimes the thread-specific agents would be playing with policies of different versions and therefore the aggregated update would not be optimal. To resolve the inconsistency, a coordinator in A2C waits for all the parallel actors to finish their work before updating the global parameters and then in the next iteration parallel actors starts from the same policy. The synchronized gradient update keeps the training more cohesive and potentially to make convergence faster.

A2C has been shown to be able to utilize GPUs more efficiently and work better with large batch sizes while achieving same or better performance than A3C.

Fig. 2. The architecture of A3C versus A2C.

DPG

[paper|code]

In methods described above, the policy function œÄ(.|s)œÄ(.|s) is always modeled as a probability distribution over actions AA given the current state and thus it is stochastic. Deterministic policy gradient (DPG) instead models the policy as a deterministic decision: a=Œº(s)a=Œº(s). It may look bizarre ‚Äî how can you calculate the gradient of the action probability when it outputs a single action? Let‚Äôs look into it step by step.

Refresh on a few notations to facilitate the discussion:

  • œÅ0(s)œÅ0(s): The initial distribution over states
  • œÅŒº(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,k)œÅŒº(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,k): Starting from state s, the visitation probability density at state s‚Äô after moving k steps by policy ŒºŒº.
  • œÅŒº(s‚Ä≤)œÅŒº(s‚Ä≤): Discounted state distribution, defined as œÅŒº(s‚Ä≤)=‚à´S‚àë‚àûk=1Œ≥k‚àí1œÅ0(s)œÅŒº(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,k)dsœÅŒº(s‚Ä≤)=‚à´S‚àëk=1‚àûŒ≥k‚àí1œÅ0(s)œÅŒº(s‚Üís‚Ä≤,k)ds.

The objective function to optimize for is listed as follows:

J(Œ∏)=‚à´SœÅŒº(s)Q(s,ŒºŒ∏(s))dsJ(Œ∏)=‚à´SœÅŒº(s)Q(s,ŒºŒ∏(s))ds

Deterministic policy gradient theorem: Now it is the time to compute the gradient! According to the chain rule, we first take the gradient of Q w.r.t. the action a and then take the gradient of the deterministic policy function ŒºŒº w.r.t. Œ∏Œ∏:

‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)=‚à´SœÅŒº(s)‚àáaQŒº(s,a)‚àáŒ∏ŒºŒ∏(s)|a=ŒºŒ∏(s)ds=Es‚àºœÅŒº[‚àáaQŒº(s,a)‚àáŒ∏ŒºŒ∏(s)|a=ŒºŒ∏(s)]‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)=‚à´SœÅŒº(s)‚àáaQŒº(s,a)‚àáŒ∏ŒºŒ∏(s)|a=ŒºŒ∏(s)ds=Es‚àºœÅŒº[‚àáaQŒº(s,a)‚àáŒ∏ŒºŒ∏(s)|a=ŒºŒ∏(s)]

We can consider the deterministic policy as a special case of the stochastic one, when the probability distribution contains only one extreme non-zero value over one action. Actually, in the DPG paper, the authors have shown that if the stochastic policy œÄŒºŒ∏,œÉœÄŒºŒ∏,œÉ is re-parameterized by a deterministic policy ŒºŒ∏ŒºŒ∏ and a variation variable œÉœÉ, the stochastic policy is eventually equivalent to the deterministic case when œÉ=0œÉ=0. Compared to the deterministic policy, we expect the stochastic policy to require more samples as it integrates the data over the whole state and action space.

The deterministic policy gradient theorem can be plugged into common policy gradient frameworks.

Let‚Äôs consider an example of on-policy actor-critic algorithm to showcase the procedure. In each iteration of on-policy actor-critic, two actions are taken deterministically a=ŒºŒ∏(s)a=ŒºŒ∏(s) and the SARSA update on policy parameters relies on the new gradient that we just computed above:

Œ¥twt+1Œ∏t+1=Rt+Œ≥Qw(st+1,at+1)‚àíQw(st,at)=wt+Œ±wŒ¥t‚àáwQw(st,at)=Œ∏t+Œ±Œ∏‚àáaQw(st,at)‚àáŒ∏ŒºŒ∏(s)|a=ŒºŒ∏(s); TD error in SARSA; Deterministic policy gradient theoremŒ¥t=Rt+Œ≥Qw(st+1,at+1)‚àíQw(st,at); TD error in SARSAwt+1=wt+Œ±wŒ¥t‚àáwQw(st,at)Œ∏t+1=Œ∏t+Œ±Œ∏‚àáaQw(st,at)‚àáŒ∏ŒºŒ∏(s)|a=ŒºŒ∏(s); Deterministic policy gradient theorem

However, unless there is sufficient noise in the environment, it is very hard to guarantee enough exploration due to the determinacy of the policy. We can either add noise into the policy (ironically this makes it nondeterministic!) or learn it off-policy-ly by following a different stochastic behavior policy to collect samples.

Say, in the off-policy approach, the training trajectories are generated by a stochastic policy Œ≤(a|s)Œ≤(a|s) and thus the state distribution follows the corresponding discounted state density œÅŒ≤œÅŒ≤:

JŒ≤(Œ∏)‚àáŒ∏JŒ≤(Œ∏)=‚à´SœÅŒ≤QŒº(s,ŒºŒ∏(s))ds=Es‚àºœÅŒ≤[‚àáaQŒº(s,a)‚àáŒ∏ŒºŒ∏(s)|a=ŒºŒ∏(s)]JŒ≤(Œ∏)=‚à´SœÅŒ≤QŒº(s,ŒºŒ∏(s))ds‚àáŒ∏JŒ≤(Œ∏)=Es‚àºœÅŒ≤[‚àáaQŒº(s,a)‚àáŒ∏ŒºŒ∏(s)|a=ŒºŒ∏(s)]

Note that because the policy is deterministic, we only need QŒº(s,ŒºŒ∏(s))QŒº(s,ŒºŒ∏(s)) rather than ‚àëaœÄ(a|s)QœÄ(s,a)‚àëaœÄ(a|s)QœÄ(s,a) as the estimated reward of a given state s. In the off-policy approach with a stochastic policy, importance sampling is often used to correct the mismatch between behavior and target policies, as what we have described above. However, because the deterministic policy gradient removes the integral over actions, we can avoid importance sampling.

DDPG

[paper|code]

DDPG (Lillicrap, et al., 2015), short for Deep Deterministic Policy Gradient, is a model-free off-policy actor-critic algorithm, combining DPG with DQN. Recall that DQN (Deep Q-Network) stabilizes the learning of Q-function by experience replay and the frozen target network. The original DQN works in discrete space, and DDPG extends it to continuous space with the actor-critic framework while learning a deterministic policy.

In order to do better exploration, an exploration policy Œº‚Ä≤Œº‚Ä≤ is constructed by adding noise NN:

Œº‚Ä≤(s)=ŒºŒ∏(s)+NŒº‚Ä≤(s)=ŒºŒ∏(s)+N

In addition, DDPG does soft updates (‚Äúconservative policy iteration‚Äù) on the parameters of both actor and critic, with œÑ‚â™1œÑ‚â™1: Œ∏‚Ä≤‚ÜêœÑŒ∏+(1‚àíœÑ)Œ∏‚Ä≤Œ∏‚Ä≤‚ÜêœÑŒ∏+(1‚àíœÑ)Œ∏‚Ä≤. In this way, the target network values are constrained to change slowly, different from the design in DQN that the target network stays frozen for some period of time.

One detail in the paper that is particularly useful in robotics is on how to normalize the different physical units of low dimensional features. For example, a model is designed to learn a policy with the robot‚Äôs positions and velocities as input; these physical statistics are different by nature and even statistics of the same type may vary a lot across multiple robots. Batch normalization is applied to fix it by normalizing every dimension across samples in one minibatch.

Fig 3. DDPG Algorithm. (Image source: Lillicrap, et al., 2015)

D4PG

[paper|code (Search ‚Äúgithub d4pg‚Äù and you will see a few.)]

Distributed Distributional DDPG (D4PG) applies a set of improvements on DDPG to make it run in the distributional fashion.

(1) Distributional Critic: The critic estimates the expected Q value as a random variable ~ a distribution ZwZw parameterized by ww and therefore Qw(s,a)=EZw(x,a)Qw(s,a)=EZw(x,a). The loss for learning the distribution parameter is to minimize some measure of the distance between two distributions ‚Äî distributional TD error: L(w)=E[d(TŒºŒ∏,Zw‚Ä≤(s,a),Zw(s,a)]L(w)=E[d(TŒºŒ∏,Zw‚Ä≤(s,a),Zw(s,a)], where TŒºŒ∏TŒºŒ∏ is the Bellman operator.

The deterministic policy gradient update becomes:

‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)‚âàEœÅŒº[‚àáaQw(s,a)‚àáŒ∏ŒºŒ∏(s)|a=ŒºŒ∏(s)]=EœÅŒº[E[‚àáaZw(s,a)]‚àáŒ∏ŒºŒ∏(s)|a=ŒºŒ∏(s)]; gradient update in DPG; expectation of the Q-value distribution.‚àáŒ∏J(Œ∏)‚âàEœÅŒº[‚àáaQw(s,a)‚àáŒ∏ŒºŒ∏(s)|a=ŒºŒ∏(s)]; gradient update in DPG=EœÅŒº[E[‚àáaZw(s,a)]‚àáŒ∏ŒºŒ∏(s)|a=ŒºŒ∏(s)]; expectation of the Q-value distribution.

(2) NN-step returns: When calculating the TD error, D4PG computes NN-step TD target rather than one-step to incorporate rewards in more future steps. Thus the new TD target is:

r(s0,a0)+E[‚àën=1N‚àí1r(sn,an)+Œ≥NQ(sN,ŒºŒ∏(sN))|s0,a0]r(s0,a0)+E[‚àën=1N‚àí1r(sn,an)+Œ≥NQ(sN,ŒºŒ∏(sN))|s0,a0]

(3) Multiple Distributed Parallel Actors: D4PG utilizes KK independent actors, gathering experience in parallel and feeding data into the same replay buffer.

(4) Prioritized Experience Replay (PER): The last piece of modification is to do sampling from the replay buffer of size RR with an non-uniform probability pipi. In this way, a sample ii has the probability (Rpi)‚àí1(Rpi)‚àí1 to be selected and thus the importance weight is (Rpi)‚àí1(Rpi)‚àí1.

Fig. 4. D4PG algorithm (Image source: Barth-Maron, et al. 2018); Note that in the original paper, the variable letters are chosen slightly differently from what in the post; i.e. I use Œº(.)Œº(.) for representing a deterministic policy instead of œÄ(.)œÄ(.).

MADDPG

[paper|code]

Multi-agent DDPG (MADDPG) (Lowe et al., 2017) extends DDPG to an environment where multiple agents are coordinating to complete tasks with only local information. In the viewpoint of one agent, the environment is non-stationary as policies of other agents are quickly upgraded and remain unknown. MADDPG is an actor-critic model redesigned particularly for handling such a changing environment and interactions between agents.

The problem can be formalized in the multi-agent version of MDP, also known as Markov games. MADDPG is proposed for partially observable Markov games. Say, there are N agents in total with a set of states SS. Each agent owns a set of possible action, A1,‚Ä¶,ANA1,‚Ä¶,AN, and a set of observation, O1,‚Ä¶,ONO1,‚Ä¶,ON. The state transition function involves all states, action and observation spaces T:S√óA1√ó‚Ä¶AN‚Ü¶ST:S√óA1√ó‚Ä¶AN‚Ü¶S. Each agent‚Äôs stochastic policy only involves its own state and action: œÄŒ∏i:Oi√óAi‚Ü¶[0,1]œÄŒ∏i:Oi√óAi‚Ü¶[0,1], a probability distribution over actions given its own observation, or a deterministic policy: ŒºŒ∏i:Oi‚Ü¶AiŒºŒ∏i:Oi‚Ü¶Ai.

Let o‚Éó =o1,‚Ä¶,oNo‚Üí=o1,‚Ä¶,oN, Œº‚Éó =Œº1,‚Ä¶,ŒºNŒº‚Üí=Œº1,‚Ä¶,ŒºN and the policies are parameterized by Œ∏‚Éó =Œ∏1,‚Ä¶,Œ∏NŒ∏‚Üí=Œ∏1,‚Ä¶,Œ∏N.

The critic in MADDPG learns a centralized action-value function QŒº‚Éó i(o‚Éó ,a1,‚Ä¶,aN)QiŒº‚Üí(o‚Üí,a1,‚Ä¶,aN) for the i-th agent, where a1‚ààA1,‚Ä¶,aN‚ààANa1‚ààA1,‚Ä¶,aN‚ààAN are actions of all agents. Each QŒº‚Éó iQiŒº‚Üí is learned separately for i=1,‚Ä¶,Ni=1,‚Ä¶,N and therefore multiple agents can have arbitrary reward structures, including conflicting rewards in a competitive setting. Meanwhile, multiple actors, one for each agent, are exploring and upgrading the policy parameters Œ∏iŒ∏i on their own.

Actor update:

‚àáŒ∏iJ(Œ∏i)=Eo‚Éó ,a‚àºD[‚àáaiQŒº‚Éó i(o‚Éó ,a1,‚Ä¶,aN)‚àáŒ∏iŒºŒ∏i(oi)|ai=ŒºŒ∏i(oi)]‚àáŒ∏iJ(Œ∏i)=Eo‚Üí,a‚àºD[‚àáaiQiŒº‚Üí(o‚Üí,a1,‚Ä¶,aN)‚àáŒ∏iŒºŒ∏i(oi)|ai=ŒºŒ∏i(oi)]

Where DD is the memory buffer for experience replay, containing multiple episode samples (o‚Éó ,a1,‚Ä¶,aN,r1,‚Ä¶,rN,o‚Éó ‚Ä≤)(o‚Üí,a1,‚Ä¶,aN,r1,‚Ä¶,rN,o‚Üí‚Ä≤) ‚Äî given current observation o‚Éó o‚Üí, agents take action a1,‚Ä¶,aNa1,‚Ä¶,aN and get rewards r1,‚Ä¶,rNr1,‚Ä¶,rN, leading to the new observation o‚Éó ‚Ä≤o‚Üí‚Ä≤.

Critic update:

L(Œ∏i)where y=Eo‚Éó ,a1,‚Ä¶,aN,r1,‚Ä¶,rN,o‚Éó ‚Ä≤[(QŒº‚Éó i(o‚Éó ,a1,‚Ä¶,aN)‚àíy)2]=ri+Œ≥QŒº‚Éó ‚Ä≤i(o‚Éó ‚Ä≤,a‚Ä≤1,‚Ä¶,a‚Ä≤N)|a‚Ä≤j=Œº‚Ä≤Œ∏j; TD target!L(Œ∏i)=Eo‚Üí,a1,‚Ä¶,aN,r1,‚Ä¶,rN,o‚Üí‚Ä≤[(QiŒº‚Üí(o‚Üí,a1,‚Ä¶,aN)‚àíy)2]where y=ri+Œ≥QiŒº‚Üí‚Ä≤(o‚Üí‚Ä≤,a1‚Ä≤,‚Ä¶,aN‚Ä≤)|aj‚Ä≤=ŒºŒ∏j‚Ä≤; TD target!

where Œº‚Éó ‚Ä≤Œº‚Üí‚Ä≤ are the target policies with delayed softly-updated parameters.

If the policies Œº‚Éó Œº‚Üí are unknown during the critic update, we can ask each agent to learn and evolve its own approximation of others‚Äô policies. Using the approximated policies, MADDPG still can learn efficiently although the inferred policies might not be accurate.

To mitigate the high variance triggered by the interaction between competing or collaborating agents in the environment, MADDPG proposed one more element - policy ensembles:

  1. Train K policies for one agent;
  2. Pick a random policy for episode rollouts;
  3. Take an ensemble of these K policies to do gradient update.

In summary, MADDPG added three additional ingredients on top of DDPG to make it adapt to the multi-agent environment:

  • Centralized critic + decentralized actors;
  • Actors are able to use estimated policies of other agents for learning;
  • Policy ensembling is good for reducing variance.

Fig. 5. The architecture design of MADDPG. (Image source: Lowe et al., 2017)

TRPO

[paper|code]

To improve training stability, we should avoid parameter updates that change the policy too much at one step. Trust region policy optimization (TRPO) (Schulman, et al., 2015) carries out this idea by enforcing a KL divergence constraint on the size of policy update at each iteration.

Consider the case when we are doing off-policy RL, the policy Œ≤Œ≤ used for collecting trajectories on rollout workers is different from the policy œÄœÄ to optimize for. The objective function in an off-policy model measures the total advantage over the state visitation distribution and actions, while the mismatch between the training data distribution and the true policy state distribution is compensated by importance sampling estimator:

J(Œ∏)=‚àës‚ààSœÅœÄŒ∏old‚àëa‚ààA(œÄŒ∏(a|s)A^Œ∏old(s,a))=‚àës‚ààSœÅœÄŒ∏old‚àëa‚ààA(Œ≤(a|s)œÄŒ∏(a|s)Œ≤(a|s)A^Œ∏old(s,a))=Es‚àºœÅœÄŒ∏old,a‚àºŒ≤[œÄŒ∏(a|s)Œ≤(a|s)A^Œ∏old(s,a)]; Importance samplingJ(Œ∏)=‚àës‚ààSœÅœÄŒ∏old‚àëa‚ààA(œÄŒ∏(a|s)A^Œ∏old(s,a))=‚àës‚ààSœÅœÄŒ∏old‚àëa‚ààA(Œ≤(a|s)œÄŒ∏(a|s)Œ≤(a|s)A^Œ∏old(s,a)); Importance sampling=Es‚àºœÅœÄŒ∏old,a‚àºŒ≤[œÄŒ∏(a|s)Œ≤(a|s)A^Œ∏old(s,a)]

where Œ∏oldŒ∏old is the policy parameters before the update and thus known to us; œÅœÄŒ∏oldœÅœÄŒ∏old is defined in the same way as above; Œ≤(a|s)Œ≤(a|s) is the behavior policy for collecting trajectories. Noted that we use an estimated advantage A^(.)A^(.) rather than the true advantage function A(.)A(.) because the true rewards are usually unknown.

When training on policy, theoretically the policy for collecting data is same as the policy that we want to optimize. However, when rollout workers and optimizers are running in parallel asynchronously, the behavior policy can get stale. TRPO considers this subtle difference: It labels the behavior policy as œÄŒ∏old(a|s)œÄŒ∏old(a|s) and thus the objective function becomes:

J(Œ∏)=Es‚àºœÅœÄŒ∏old,a‚àºœÄŒ∏old[œÄŒ∏(a|s)œÄŒ∏old(a|s)A^Œ∏old(s,a)]J(Œ∏)=Es‚àºœÅœÄŒ∏old,a‚àºœÄŒ∏old[œÄŒ∏(a|s)œÄŒ∏old(a|s)A^Œ∏old(s,a)]

TRPO aims to maximize the objective function J(Œ∏)J(Œ∏) subject to, trust region constraint which enforces the distance between old and new policies measured by KL-divergence to be small enough, within a parameter Œ¥:

Es‚àºœÅœÄŒ∏old[DKL(œÄŒ∏old(.|s)‚à•œÄŒ∏(.|s)]‚â§Œ¥Es‚àºœÅœÄŒ∏old[DKL(œÄŒ∏old(.|s)‚ÄñœÄŒ∏(.|s)]‚â§Œ¥

In this way, the old and new policies would not diverge too much when this hard constraint is met. While still, TRPO can guarantee a monotonic improvement over policy iteration (Neat, right?). Please read the proof in the paper if interested :)

PPO

[paper|code]

Given that TRPO is relatively complicated and we still want to implement a similar constraint, proximal policy optimization (PPO) simplifies it by using a clipped surrogate objective while retaining similar performance.

First, let‚Äôs denote the probability ratio between old and new policies as:

r(Œ∏)=œÄŒ∏(a|s)œÄŒ∏old(a|s)r(Œ∏)=œÄŒ∏(a|s)œÄŒ∏old(a|s)

Then, the objective function of TRPO (on policy) becomes:

JTRPO(Œ∏)=E[r(Œ∏)A^Œ∏old(s,a)]JTRPO(Œ∏)=E[r(Œ∏)A^Œ∏old(s,a)]

Without a limitation on the distance between Œ∏oldŒ∏old and Œ∏Œ∏, to maximize JTRPO(Œ∏)JTRPO(Œ∏) would lead to instability with extremely large parameter updates and big policy ratios. PPO imposes the constraint by forcing r(Œ∏)r(Œ∏) to stay within a small interval around 1, precisely [1‚àíœµ,1+œµ][1‚àíœµ,1+œµ], where œµœµ is a hyperparameter.

JCLIP(Œ∏)=E[min(r(Œ∏)A^Œ∏old(s,a),clip(r(Œ∏),1‚àíœµ,1+œµ)A^Œ∏old(s,a))]JCLIP(Œ∏)=E[min(r(Œ∏)A^Œ∏old(s,a),clip(r(Œ∏),1‚àíœµ,1+œµ)A^Œ∏old(s,a))]

The function clip(r(Œ∏),1‚àíœµ,1+œµ)clip(r(Œ∏),1‚àíœµ,1+œµ) clips the ratio to be no more than 1+œµ1+œµ and no less than 1‚àíœµ1‚àíœµ. The objective function of PPO takes the minimum one between the original value and the clipped version and therefore we lose the motivation for increasing the policy update to extremes for better rewards.

When applying PPO on the network architecture with shared parameters for both policy (actor) and value (critic) functions, in addition to the clipped reward, the objective function is augmented with an error term on the value estimation (formula in red) and an entropy term (formula in blue) to encourage sufficient exploration.

JCLIP'(Œ∏)=E[JCLIP(Œ∏)‚àíc1(VŒ∏(s)‚àíVtarget)2+c2H(s,œÄŒ∏(.))]JCLIP'(Œ∏)=E[JCLIP(Œ∏)‚àíc1(VŒ∏(s)‚àíVtarget)2+c2H(s,œÄŒ∏(.))]

where Both c1c1 and c2c2 are two hyperparameter constants.

PPO has been tested on a set of benchmark tasks and proved to produce awesome results with much greater simplicity.

In a later paper by Hsu et al., 2020, two common design choices in PPO are revisited, precisely (1) clipped probability ratio for policy regularization and (2) parameterize policy action space by continuous Gaussian or discrete softmax distribution. They first identified three failure modes in PPO and proposed replacements for these two designs.

The failure modes are:

  1. On continuous action spaces, standard PPO is unstable when rewards vanish outside bounded support.
  2. On discrete action spaces with sparse high rewards, standard PPO often gets stuck at suboptimal actions.
  3. The policy is sensitive to initialization when there are locally optimal actions close to initialization.

Discretizing the action space or use Beta distribution helps avoid failure mode 1&3 associated with Gaussian policy. Using KL regularization (same motivation as in TRPO) as an alternative surrogate model helps resolve failure mode 1&2.

PPG

[paper|code]

Sharing parameters between policy and value networks have pros and cons. It allows policy and value functions to share the learned features with each other, but it may cause conflicts between competing objectives and demands the same data for training two networks at the same time. Phasic policy gradient (PPG; Cobbe, et al 2020) modifies the traditional on-policy actor-critic policy gradient algorithm. precisely PPO, to have separate training phases for policy and value functions. In two alternating phases:

  1. The policy phase: updates the policy network by optimizing the PPO objective LCLIP(Œ∏)LCLIP(Œ∏);
  2. The auxiliary phase: optimizes an auxiliary objective alongside a behavioral cloning loss. In the paper, value function error is the sole auxiliary objective, but it can be quite general and includes any other additional auxiliary losses.
LjointLaux=Laux+Œ≤clone‚ãÖEt[KL[œÄŒ∏old(‚ãÖ‚à£st),œÄŒ∏(‚ãÖ‚à£st)]]=Lvalue=Et[12(Vw(st)‚àíV^targt)2]Ljoint=Laux+Œ≤clone‚ãÖEt[KL[œÄŒ∏old(‚ãÖ‚à£st),œÄŒ∏(‚ãÖ‚à£st)]]Laux=Lvalue=Et[12(Vw(st)‚àíV^ttarg)2]

where Œ≤cloneŒ≤clone is a hyperparameter for controlling how much we would like to keep the policy not diverge too much from its original behavior while optimizing the auxiliary objectives.

Fig. 6. The algorithm of PPG. (Image source: Cobbe, et al 2020)

where

  • NœÄNœÄ is the number of policy update iterations in the policy phase. Note that the policy phase performs multiple iterations of updates per single auxiliary phase.
  • EœÄEœÄ and EVEV control the sample reuse (i.e. the number of training epochs performed across data in the reply buffer) for the policy and value functions, respectively. Note that this happens within the policy phase and thus EVEV affects the learning of true value function not the auxiliary value function.
  • EauxEaux defines the sample reuse in the auxiliary phrase. In PPG, value function optimization can tolerate a much higher level sample reuse; for example, in the experiments of the paper, Eaux=6Eaux=6 while EœÄ=EV=1EœÄ=EV=1.

PPG leads to a significant improvement on sample efficiency compared to PPO.

Fig. 7. The mean normalized performance of PPG vs PPO on the Procgen benchmark. (Image source: Cobbe, et al 2020)

ACER

[paper|code]

ACER, short for actor-critic with experience replay (Wang, et al., 2017), is an off-policy actor-critic model with experience replay, greatly increasing the sample efficiency and decreasing the data correlation. A3C builds up the foundation for ACER, but it is on policy; ACER is A3C‚Äôs off-policy counterpart. The major obstacle to making A3C off policy is how to control the stability of the off-policy estimator. ACER proposes three designs to overcome it:

  • Use Retrace Q-value estimation;
  • Truncate the importance weights with bias correction;
  • Apply efficient TRPO.

Retrace Q-value Estimation

Retrace is an off-policy return-based Q-value estimation algorithm with a nice guarantee for convergence for any target and behavior policy pair (œÄ,Œ≤)(œÄ,Œ≤), plus good data efficiency.

Recall how TD learning works for prediction:

  1. Compute TD error: Œ¥t=Rt+Œ≥Ea‚àºœÄQ(St+1,a)‚àíQ(St,At)Œ¥t=Rt+Œ≥Ea‚àºœÄQ(St+1,a)‚àíQ(St,At); the term rt+Œ≥Ea‚àºœÄQ(st+1,a)rt+Œ≥Ea‚àºœÄQ(st+1,a) is known as ‚ÄúTD target‚Äù. The expectation Ea‚àºœÄEa‚àºœÄ is used because for the future step the best estimation we can make is what the return would be if we follow the current policy œÄœÄ.
  2. Update the value by correcting the error to move toward the goal: Q(St,At)‚ÜêQ(St,At)+Œ±Œ¥tQ(St,At)‚ÜêQ(St,At)+Œ±Œ¥t. In other words, the incremental update on Q is proportional to the TD error: ŒîQ(St,At)=Œ±Œ¥tŒîQ(St,At)=Œ±Œ¥t.

When the rollout is off policy, we need to apply importance sampling on the Q update:

ŒîQimp(St,At)=Œ≥t‚àè1‚â§œÑ‚â§tœÄ(AœÑ|SœÑ)Œ≤(AœÑ|SœÑ)Œ¥tŒîQimp(St,At)=Œ≥t‚àè1‚â§œÑ‚â§tœÄ(AœÑ|SœÑ)Œ≤(AœÑ|SœÑ)Œ¥t

The product of importance weights looks pretty scary when we start imagining how it can cause super high variance and even explode. Retrace Q-value estimation method modifies ŒîQŒîQ to have importance weights truncated by no more than a constant cc:

ŒîQret(St,At)=Œ≥t‚àè1‚â§œÑ‚â§tmin(c,œÄ(AœÑ|SœÑ)Œ≤(AœÑ|SœÑ))Œ¥tŒîQret(St,At)=Œ≥t‚àè1‚â§œÑ‚â§tmin(c,œÄ(AœÑ|SœÑ)Œ≤(AœÑ|SœÑ))Œ¥t

ACER uses QretQret as the target to train the critic by minimizing the L2 error term: (Qret(s,a)‚àíQ(s,a))2(Qret(s,a)‚àíQ(s,a))2.

Importance weights truncation

To reduce the high variance of the policy gradient g^g^, ACER truncates the importance weights by a constant c, plus a correction term. The label g^acertg^tacer is the ACER policy gradient at time t.

g^acert==œât(Qret(St,At)‚àíVŒ∏v(St))‚àáŒ∏lnœÄŒ∏(At|St)min(c,œât)(Qret(St,At)‚àíVw(St))‚àáŒ∏lnœÄŒ∏(At|St)+Ea‚àºœÄ[max(0,œât(a)‚àícœât(a))(Qw(St,a)‚àíVw(St))‚àáŒ∏lnœÄŒ∏(a|St)]; Let œât=œÄ(At|St)Œ≤(At|St); Let œât(a)=œÄ(a|St)Œ≤(a|St)g^tacer=œât(Qret(St,At)‚àíVŒ∏v(St))‚àáŒ∏ln‚Å°œÄŒ∏(At|St); Let œât=œÄ(At|St)Œ≤(At|St)=min(c,œât)(Qret(St,At)‚àíVw(St))‚àáŒ∏ln‚Å°œÄŒ∏(At|St)+Ea‚àºœÄ[max(0,œât(a)‚àícœât(a))(Qw(St,a)‚àíVw(St))‚àáŒ∏ln‚Å°œÄŒ∏(a|St)]; Let œât(a)=œÄ(a|St)Œ≤(a|St)

where Qw(.)Qw(.) and Vw(.)Vw(.) are value functions predicted by the critic with parameter w. The first term (blue) contains the clipped important weight. The clipping helps reduce the variance, in addition to subtracting state value function Vw(.)Vw(.) as a baseline. The second term (red) makes a correction to achieve unbiased estimation.

Efficient TRPO

Furthermore, ACER adopts the idea of TRPO but with a small adjustment to make it more computationally efficient: rather than measuring the KL divergence between policies before and after one update, ACER maintains a running average of past policies and forces the updated policy to not deviate far from this average.

The ACER paper is pretty dense with many equations. Hopefully, with the prior knowledge on TD learning, Q-learning, importance sampling and TRPO, you will find the paper slightly easier to follow :)

ACTKR

[paper|code]

ACKTR (actor-critic using Kronecker-factored trust region) (Yuhuai Wu, et al., 2017) proposed to use Kronecker-factored approximation curvature (K-FAC) to do the gradient update for both the critic and actor. K-FAC made an improvement on the computation of natural gradient, which is quite different from our standard gradient. Here is a nice, intuitive explanation of natural gradient. One sentence summary is probably:

‚Äúwe first consider all combinations of parameters that result in a new network a constant KL divergence away from the old network. This constant value can be viewed as the step size or learning rate. Out of all these possible combinations, we choose the one that minimizes our loss function.‚Äù

I listed ACTKR here mainly for the completeness of this post, but I would not dive into details, as it involves a lot of theoretical knowledge on natural gradient and optimization methods. If interested, check these papers/posts, before reading the ACKTR paper:

  • Amari. Natural Gradient Works Efficiently in Learning. 1998
  • Kakade. A Natural Policy Gradient. 2002
  • A intuitive explanation of natural gradient descent
  • Wiki: Kronecker product
  • Martens & Grosse. Optimizing neural networks with kronecker-factored approximate curvature. 2015.

Here is a high level summary from the K-FAC paper:

‚ÄúThis approximation is built in two stages. In the first, the rows and columns of the Fisher are divided into groups, each of which corresponds to all the weights in a given layer, and this gives rise to a block-partitioning of the matrix. These blocks are then approximated as Kronecker products between much smaller matrices, which we show is equivalent to making certain approximating assumptions regarding the statistics of the network‚Äôs gradients.

In the second stage, this matrix is further approximated as having an inverse which is either block-diagonal or block-tridiagonal. We justify this approximation through a careful examination of the relationships between inverse covariances, tree-structured graphical models, and linear regression. Notably, this justification doesn‚Äôt apply to the Fisher itself, and our experiments confirm that while the inverse Fisher does indeed possess this structure (approximately), the Fisher itself does not.‚Äù

SAC

[paper|code]

Soft Actor-Critic (SAC) (Haarnoja et al. 2018) incorporates the entropy measure of the policy into the reward to encourage exploration: we expect to learn a policy that acts as randomly as possible while it is still able to succeed at the task. It is an off-policy actor-critic model following the maximum entropy reinforcement learning framework. A precedent work is Soft Q-learning.

Three key components in SAC:

  • An actor-critic architecture with separate policy and value function networks;
  • An off-policy formulation that enables reuse of previously collected data for efficiency;
  • Entropy maximization to enable stability and exploration.

The policy is trained with the objective to maximize the expected return and the entropy at the same time:

J(Œ∏)=‚àët=1TE(st,at)‚àºœÅœÄŒ∏[r(st,at)+Œ±H(œÄŒ∏(.|st))]J(Œ∏)=‚àët=1TE(st,at)‚àºœÅœÄŒ∏[r(st,at)+Œ±H(œÄŒ∏(.|st))]

where H(.)H(.) is the entropy measure and Œ±Œ± controls how important the entropy term is, known as temperature parameter. The entropy maximization leads to policies that can (1) explore more and (2) capture multiple modes of near-optimal strategies (i.e., if there exist multiple options that seem to be equally good, the policy should assign each with an equal probability to be chosen).

Precisely, SAC aims to learn three functions:

  • The policy with parameter Œ∏Œ∏, œÄŒ∏œÄŒ∏.
  • Soft Q-value function parameterized by ww, QwQw.
  • Soft state value function parameterized by œàœà, VœàVœà; theoretically we can infer VV by knowing QQ and œÄœÄ, but in practice, it helps stabilize the training.

Soft Q-value and soft state value are defined as:

Q(st,at)where V(st)=r(st,at)+Œ≥Est+1‚àºœÅœÄ(s)[V(st+1)]=Eat‚àºœÄ[Q(st,at)‚àíŒ±logœÄ(at|st)]; according to Bellman equation.; soft state value function.Q(st,at)=r(st,at)+Œ≥Est+1‚àºœÅœÄ(s)[V(st+1)]; according to Bellman equation.where V(st)=Eat‚àºœÄ[Q(st,at)‚àíŒ±log‚Å°œÄ(at|st)]; soft state value function.
Thus, Q(st,at)=r(st,at)+Œ≥E(st+1,at+1)‚àºœÅœÄ[Q(st+1,at+1)‚àíŒ±logœÄ(at+1|st+1)]Thus, Q(st,at)=r(st,at)+Œ≥E(st+1,at+1)‚àºœÅœÄ[Q(st+1,at+1)‚àíŒ±log‚Å°œÄ(at+1|st+1)]

œÅœÄ(s)œÅœÄ(s) and œÅœÄ(s,a)œÅœÄ(s,a) denote the state and the state-action marginals of the state distribution induced by the policy œÄ(a|s)œÄ(a|s); see the similar definitions in DPG section.

The soft state value function is trained to minimize the mean squared error:

JV(œà)with gradient: ‚àáœàJV(œà)=Est‚àºD[12(Vœà(st)‚àíE[Qw(st,at)‚àílogœÄŒ∏(at|st)])2]=‚àáœàVœà(st)(Vœà(st)‚àíQw(st,at)+logœÄŒ∏(at|st))JV(œà)=Est‚àºD[12(Vœà(st)‚àíE[Qw(st,at)‚àílog‚Å°œÄŒ∏(at|st)])2]with gradient: ‚àáœàJV(œà)=‚àáœàVœà(st)(Vœà(st)‚àíQw(st,at)+log‚Å°œÄŒ∏(at|st))

where DD is the replay buffer.

The soft Q function is trained to minimize the soft Bellman residual:

JQ(w)with gradient: ‚àáwJQ(w)=E(st,at)‚àºD[12(Qw(st,at)‚àí(r(st,at)+Œ≥Est+1‚àºœÅœÄ(s)[Vœà¬Ø(st+1)]))2]=‚àáwQw(st,at)(Qw(st,at)‚àír(st,at)‚àíŒ≥Vœà¬Ø(st+1))JQ(w)=E(st,at)‚àºD[12(Qw(st,at)‚àí(r(st,at)+Œ≥Est+1‚àºœÅœÄ(s)[Vœà¬Ø(st+1)]))2]with gradient: ‚àáwJQ(w)=‚àáwQw(st,at)(Qw(st,at)‚àír(st,at)‚àíŒ≥Vœà¬Ø(st+1))

where œà¬Øœà¬Ø is the target value function which is the exponential moving average (or only gets updated periodically in a ‚Äúhard‚Äù way), just like how the parameter of the target Q network is treated in DQN to stabilize the training.

SAC updates the policy to minimize the KL-divergence:

œÄnewobjective for update: JœÄ(Œ∏)=argminœÄ‚Ä≤‚ààŒ†DKL(œÄ‚Ä≤(.|st)‚à•exp(QœÄold(st,.))ZœÄold(st))=argminœÄ‚Ä≤‚ààŒ†DKL(œÄ‚Ä≤(.|st)‚à•exp(QœÄold(st,.)‚àílogZœÄold(st)))=‚àáŒ∏DKL(œÄŒ∏(.|st)‚à•exp(Qw(st,.)‚àílogZw(st)))=Eat‚àºœÄ[‚àílog(exp(Qw(st,at)‚àílogZw(st))œÄŒ∏(at|st))]=Eat‚àºœÄ[logœÄŒ∏(at|st)‚àíQw(st,at)+logZw(st)]œÄnew=arg‚Å°minœÄ‚Ä≤‚ààŒ†DKL(œÄ‚Ä≤(.|st)‚Äñexp‚Å°(QœÄold(st,.))ZœÄold(st))=arg‚Å°minœÄ‚Ä≤‚ààŒ†DKL(œÄ‚Ä≤(.|st)‚Äñexp‚Å°(QœÄold(st,.)‚àílog‚Å°ZœÄold(st)))objective for update: JœÄ(Œ∏)=‚àáŒ∏DKL(œÄŒ∏(.|st)‚Äñexp‚Å°(Qw(st,.)‚àílog‚Å°Zw(st)))=Eat‚àºœÄ[‚àílog‚Å°(exp‚Å°(Qw(st,at)‚àílog‚Å°Zw(st))œÄŒ∏(at|st))]=Eat‚àºœÄ[log‚Å°œÄŒ∏(at|st)‚àíQw(st,at)+log‚Å°Zw(st)]

where Œ†Œ† is the set of potential policies that we can model our policy as to keep them tractable; for example, Œ†Œ† can be the family of Gaussian mixture distributions, expensive to model but highly expressive and still tractable. ZœÄold(st)ZœÄold(st) is the partition function to normalize the distribution. It is usually intractable but does not contribute to the gradient. How to minimize JœÄ(Œ∏)JœÄ(Œ∏) depends our choice of Œ†Œ†.

This update guarantees that QœÄnew(st,at)‚â•QœÄold(st,at)QœÄnew(st,at)‚â•QœÄold(st,at), please check the proof on this lemma in the Appendix B.2 in the original paper.

Once we have defined the objective functions and gradients for soft action-state value, soft state value and the policy network, the soft actor-critic algorithm is straightforward:

SAC with Automatically Adjusted Temperature

[paper|code]

SAC is brittle with respect to the temperature parameter. Unfortunately it is difficult to adjust temperature, because the entropy can vary unpredictably both across tasks and during training as the policy becomes better. An improvement on SAC formulates a constrained optimization problem: while maximizing the expected return, the policy should satisfy a minimum entropy constraint:

maxœÄ0,‚Ä¶,œÄTE[‚àët=0Tr(st,at)]s.t. ‚àÄt, H(œÄt)‚â•H0maxœÄ0,‚Ä¶,œÄTE[‚àët=0Tr(st,at)]s.t. ‚àÄt, H(œÄt)‚â•H0

where H0H0 is a predefined minimum policy entropy threshold.

The expected return E[‚àëTt=0r(st,at)]E[‚àët=0Tr(st,at)] can be decomposed into a sum of rewards at all the time steps. Because the policy œÄtœÄt at time t has no effect on the policy at the earlier time step, œÄt‚àí1œÄt‚àí1, we can maximize the return at different steps backward in time ‚Äî this is essentially DP.

maxœÄ0(E[r(s0,a0)]+maxœÄ1(E[...]+maxœÄTE[r(sT,aT)]ÓÖíÓÖìÓÖëÓÖêÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖî1st maximization)ÓÖíÓÖìÓÖëÓÖêÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîsecond but last maximization)ÓÖíÓÖìÓÖëÓÖêÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîlast maximizationmaxœÄ0(E[r(s0,a0)]+maxœÄ1(E[...]+maxœÄTE[r(sT,aT)]‚èü1st maximization)‚èüsecond but last maximization)‚èülast maximization

where we consider Œ≥=1Œ≥=1.

maximize f(œÄT) s.t. h(œÄT)‚â•0maximize f(œÄT) s.t. h(œÄT)‚â•0

To solve the maximization optimization with inequality constraint, we can construct a Lagrangian expression with a Lagrange multiplier (also known as ‚Äúdual variable‚Äù), Œ±TŒ±T:

L(œÄT,Œ±T)=f(œÄT)+Œ±Th(œÄT)L(œÄT,Œ±T)=f(œÄT)+Œ±Th(œÄT)

Considering the case when we try to minimize L(œÄT,Œ±T)L(œÄT,Œ±T) with respect to Œ±TŒ±T - given a particular value œÄTœÄT,

f(œÄT)=minŒ±T‚â•0L(œÄT,Œ±T)f(œÄT)=minŒ±T‚â•0L(œÄT,Œ±T)

œÄ‚àóTŒ±‚àóT=argmaxœÄTE(sT,aT)‚àºœÅœÄ[r(sT,aT)+Œ±TH(œÄT)‚àíŒ±TH0]=argminŒ±T‚â•0E(sT,aT)‚àºœÅœÄ‚àó[Œ±TH(œÄ‚àóT)‚àíŒ±TH0]œÄT‚àó=arg‚Å°maxœÄTE(sT,aT)‚àºœÅœÄ[r(sT,aT)+Œ±TH(œÄT)‚àíŒ±TH0]Œ±T‚àó=arg‚Å°minŒ±T‚â•0E(sT,aT)‚àºœÅœÄ‚àó[Œ±TH(œÄT‚àó)‚àíŒ±TH0]
Thus, maxœÄTE[r(sT,aT)]=E(sT,aT)‚àºœÅœÄ‚àó[r(sT,aT)+Œ±‚àóTH(œÄ‚àóT)‚àíŒ±‚àóTH0]Thus, maxœÄTE[r(sT,aT)]=E(sT,aT)‚àºœÅœÄ‚àó[r(sT,aT)+Œ±T‚àóH(œÄT‚àó)‚àíŒ±T‚àóH0]

TD3

[paper|code]

The Q-learning algorithm is commonly known to suffer from the overestimation of the value function. This overestimation can propagate through the training iterations and negatively affect the policy. This property directly motivated Double Q-learning and Double DQN: the action selection and Q-value update are decoupled by using two value networks.

Twin Delayed Deep Deterministic (short for TD3; Fujimoto et al., 2018) applied a couple of tricks on DDPG to prevent the overestimation of the value function:

(1) Clipped Double Q-learning: In Double Q-Learning, the action selection and Q-value estimation are made by two networks separately. In the DDPG setting, given two deterministic actors (ŒºŒ∏1,ŒºŒ∏2)(ŒºŒ∏1,ŒºŒ∏2) with two corresponding critics (Qw1,Qw2)(Qw1,Qw2), the Double Q-learning Bellman targets look like:

y1y2=r+Œ≥Qw2(s‚Ä≤,ŒºŒ∏1(s‚Ä≤))=r+Œ≥Qw1(s‚Ä≤,ŒºŒ∏2(s‚Ä≤))y1=r+Œ≥Qw2(s‚Ä≤,ŒºŒ∏1(s‚Ä≤))y2=r+Œ≥Qw1(s‚Ä≤,ŒºŒ∏2(s‚Ä≤))

However, due to the slow changing policy, these two networks could be too similar to make independent decisions. The Clipped Double Q-learning instead uses the minimum estimation among two so as to favor underestimation bias which is hard to propagate through training:

y1y2=r+Œ≥mini=1,2Qwi(s‚Ä≤,ŒºŒ∏1(s‚Ä≤))=r+Œ≥mini=1,2Qwi(s‚Ä≤,ŒºŒ∏2(s‚Ä≤))y1=r+Œ≥mini=1,2Qwi(s‚Ä≤,ŒºŒ∏1(s‚Ä≤))y2=r+Œ≥mini=1,2Qwi(s‚Ä≤,ŒºŒ∏2(s‚Ä≤))

(2) Delayed update of Target and Policy Networks: In the actor-critic model, policy and value updates are deeply coupled: Value estimates diverge through overestimation when the policy is poor, and the policy will become poor if the value estimate itself is inaccurate.

To reduce the variance, TD3 updates the policy at a lower frequency than the Q-function. The policy network stays the same until the value error is small enough after several updates. The idea is similar to how the periodically-updated target network stay as a stable objective in DQN.

(3) Target Policy Smoothing: Given a concern with deterministic policies that they can overfit to narrow peaks in the value function, TD3 introduced a smoothing regularization strategy on the value function: adding a small amount of clipped random noises to the selected action and averaging over mini-batches.

yœµ=r+Œ≥Qw(s‚Ä≤,ŒºŒ∏(s‚Ä≤)+œµ)‚àºclip(N(0,œÉ),‚àíc,+c) ; clipped random noises.y=r+Œ≥Qw(s‚Ä≤,ŒºŒ∏(s‚Ä≤)+œµ)œµ‚àºclip(N(0,œÉ),‚àíc,+c) ; clipped random noises.

This approach mimics the idea of SARSA update and enforces that similar actions should have similar values.

Here is the final algorithm:

Fig. 10. TD3 Algorithm. (Image source: Fujimoto et al., 2018)

SVPG

[paper|code for SVPG]

Stein Variational Policy Gradient (SVPG; Liu et al, 2017) applies the Stein variational gradient descent (SVGD; Liu and Wang, 2016) algorithm to update the policy parameter Œ∏Œ∏.

In the setup of maximum entropy policy optimization, Œ∏Œ∏ is considered as a random variable Œ∏‚àºq(Œ∏)Œ∏‚àºq(Œ∏) and the model is expected to learn this distribution q(Œ∏)q(Œ∏). Assuming we know a prior on how qq might look like, q0q0, and we would like to guide the learning process to not make Œ∏Œ∏ too far away from q0q0 by optimizing the following objective function:

J^(Œ∏)=EŒ∏‚àºq[J(Œ∏)]‚àíŒ±DKL(q‚à•q0)J^(Œ∏)=EŒ∏‚àºq[J(Œ∏)]‚àíŒ±DKL(q‚Äñq0)

where EŒ∏‚àºq[R(Œ∏)]EŒ∏‚àºq[R(Œ∏)] is the expected reward when Œ∏‚àºq(Œ∏)Œ∏‚àºq(Œ∏) and DKLDKL is the KL divergence.

If we don‚Äôt have any prior information, we might set q0q0 as a uniform distribution and set q0(Œ∏)q0(Œ∏) to a constant. Then the above objective function becomes SAC, where the entropy term encourages exploration:

J^(Œ∏)=EŒ∏‚àºq[J(Œ∏)]‚àíŒ±DKL(q‚à•q0)=EŒ∏‚àºq[J(Œ∏)]‚àíŒ±EŒ∏‚àºq[logq(Œ∏)‚àílogq0(Œ∏)]=EŒ∏‚àºq[J(Œ∏)]+Œ±H(q(Œ∏))J^(Œ∏)=EŒ∏‚àºq[J(Œ∏)]‚àíŒ±DKL(q‚Äñq0)=EŒ∏‚àºq[J(Œ∏)]‚àíŒ±EŒ∏‚àºq[log‚Å°q(Œ∏)‚àílog‚Å°q0(Œ∏)]=EŒ∏‚àºq[J(Œ∏)]+Œ±H(q(Œ∏))

Let‚Äôs take the derivative of J^(Œ∏)=EŒ∏‚àºq[J(Œ∏)]‚àíŒ±DKL(q‚à•q0)J^(Œ∏)=EŒ∏‚àºq[J(Œ∏)]‚àíŒ±DKL(q‚Äñq0) w.r.t. qq:

‚àáqJ^(Œ∏)=‚àáq(EŒ∏‚àºq[J(Œ∏)]‚àíŒ±DKL(q‚à•q0))=‚àáq‚à´Œ∏(q(Œ∏)J(Œ∏)‚àíŒ±q(Œ∏)logq(Œ∏)+Œ±q(Œ∏)logq0(Œ∏))=‚à´Œ∏(J(Œ∏)‚àíŒ±logq(Œ∏)‚àíŒ±+Œ±logq0(Œ∏))=0‚àáqJ^(Œ∏)=‚àáq(EŒ∏‚àºq[J(Œ∏)]‚àíŒ±DKL(q‚Äñq0))=‚àáq‚à´Œ∏(q(Œ∏)J(Œ∏)‚àíŒ±q(Œ∏)log‚Å°q(Œ∏)+Œ±q(Œ∏)log‚Å°q0(Œ∏))=‚à´Œ∏(J(Œ∏)‚àíŒ±log‚Å°q(Œ∏)‚àíŒ±+Œ±log‚Å°q0(Œ∏))=0

The optimal distribution is:

logq‚àó(Œ∏)=1Œ±J(Œ∏)+logq0(Œ∏)‚àí1 thus q‚àó(Œ∏)ÓÖíÓÖìÓÖëÓÖêÓÖîÓÖî"posterior"‚àùexp(J(Œ∏)/Œ±)ÓÖíÓÖìÓÖëÓÖêÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖîÓÖî"likelihood"q0(Œ∏)ÓÖíÓÖìÓÖëÓÖêÓÖîÓÖîpriorlog‚Å°q‚àó(Œ∏)=1Œ±J(Œ∏)+log‚Å°q0(Œ∏)‚àí1 thus q‚àó(Œ∏)‚èü"posterior"‚àùexp‚Å°(J(Œ∏)/Œ±)‚èü"likelihood"q0(Œ∏)‚èüprior

The temperature Œ±Œ± decides a tradeoff between exploitation and exploration. When Œ±‚Üí0Œ±‚Üí0, Œ∏Œ∏ is updated only according to the expected return J(Œ∏)J(Œ∏). When Œ±‚Üí‚àûŒ±‚Üí‚àû, Œ∏Œ∏ always follows the prior belief.

When using the SVGD method to estimate the target posterior distribution q(Œ∏)q(Œ∏), it relies on a set of particle {Œ∏i}ni=1{Œ∏i}i=1n (independently trained policy agents) and each is updated:

Œ∏i‚ÜêŒ∏i+œµœï‚àó(Œ∏i) where œï‚àó=maxœï‚ààH{‚àí‚àáœµDKL(q‚Ä≤[Œ∏+œµœï(Œ∏)]‚à•q) s.t. ‚à•œï‚à•H‚â§1}Œ∏i‚ÜêŒ∏i+œµœï‚àó(Œ∏i) where œï‚àó=maxœï‚ààH{‚àí‚àáœµDKL(q[Œ∏+œµœï(Œ∏)]‚Ä≤‚Äñq) s.t. ‚Äñœï‚ÄñH‚â§1}

where œµœµ is a learning rate and œï‚àóœï‚àó is the unit ball of a RKHS (reproducing kernel Hilbert space) HH of Œ∏Œ∏-shaped value vectors that maximally decreases the KL divergence between the particles and the target distribution. q‚Ä≤(.)q‚Ä≤(.) is the distribution of Œ∏+œµœï(Œ∏)Œ∏+œµœï(Œ∏).

Comparing different gradient-based update methods:

œï‚àó(Œ∏i)=Eœë‚àºq‚Ä≤[‚àáœëlogq(œë)k(œë,Œ∏i)+‚àáœëk(œë,Œ∏i)]=1n‚àëj=1n[‚àáŒ∏jlogq(Œ∏j)k(Œ∏j,Œ∏i)+‚àáŒ∏jk(Œ∏j,Œ∏i)];approximate q‚Ä≤ with current particle valuesœï‚àó(Œ∏i)=Eœë‚àºq‚Ä≤[‚àáœëlog‚Å°q(œë)k(œë,Œ∏i)+‚àáœëk(œë,Œ∏i)]=1n‚àëj=1n[‚àáŒ∏jlog‚Å°q(Œ∏j)k(Œ∏j,Œ∏i)+‚àáŒ∏jk(Œ∏j,Œ∏i)];approximate q‚Ä≤ with current particle values
  • The first term in red encourages Œ∏iŒ∏i learning towards the high probability regions of qq that is shared across similar particles. => to be similar to other particles
  • The second term in green pushes particles away from each other and therefore diversifies the policy. => to be dissimilar to other particles

Usually the temperature Œ±Œ± follows an annealing scheme so that the training process does more exploration at the beginning but more exploitation at a later stage.

IMPALA

[paper|code]

In order to scale up RL training to achieve a very high throughput, IMPALA (‚ÄúImportance Weighted Actor-Learner Architecture‚Äù) framework decouples acting from learning on top of basic actor-critic setup and learns from all experience trajectories with V-trace off-policy correction.

Multiple actors generate experience in parallel, while the learner optimizes both policy and value function parameters using all the generated experience. Actors update their parameters with the latest policy from the learner periodically. Because acting and learning are decoupled, we can add many more actor machines to generate a lot more trajectories per time unit. As the training policy and the behavior policy are not totally synchronized, there is a gap between them and thus we need off-policy corrections.

Let the value function VŒ∏VŒ∏ parameterized by Œ∏Œ∏ and the policy œÄœïœÄœï parameterized by œïœï. Also we know the trajectories in the replay buffer are collected by a slightly older policy ŒºŒº.

At the training time tt, given (st,at,st+1,rt)(st,at,st+1,rt), the value function parameter Œ∏Œ∏ is learned through an L2 loss between the current value and a V-trace value target. The nn-step V-trace target is defined as:

vt=VŒ∏(st)+‚àëi=tt+n‚àí1Œ≥i‚àít(‚àèj=ti‚àí1cj)Œ¥iV=VŒ∏(st)+‚àëi=tt+n‚àí1Œ≥i‚àít(‚àèj=ti‚àí1cj)œÅi(ri+Œ≥VŒ∏(si+1)‚àíVŒ∏(si))vt=VŒ∏(st)+‚àëi=tt+n‚àí1Œ≥i‚àít(‚àèj=ti‚àí1cj)Œ¥iV=VŒ∏(st)+‚àëi=tt+n‚àí1Œ≥i‚àít(‚àèj=ti‚àí1cj)œÅi(ri+Œ≥VŒ∏(si+1)‚àíVŒ∏(si))

where the red part Œ¥iVŒ¥iV is a temporal difference for VV. œÅi=min(œÅ¬Ø,œÄ(ai|si)Œº(ai|si))œÅi=min(œÅ¬Ø,œÄ(ai|si)Œº(ai|si)) and cj=min(c¬Ø,œÄ(aj|sj)Œº(aj|sj))cj=min(c¬Ø,œÄ(aj|sj)Œº(aj|sj)) are truncated importance sampling (IS) weights. The product of ct,‚Ä¶,ci‚àí1ct,‚Ä¶,ci‚àí1 measures how much a temporal difference Œ¥iVŒ¥iV observed at time ii impacts the update of the value function at a previous time tt. In the on-policy case, we have œÅi=1œÅi=1 and cj=1cj=1 (assuming c¬Ø‚â•1c¬Ø‚â•1) and therefore the V-trace target becomes on-policy nn-step Bellman target.

œÅ¬ØœÅ¬Ø and c¬Øc¬Ø are two truncation constants with œÅ¬Ø‚â•c¬ØœÅ¬Ø‚â•c¬Ø. œÅ¬ØœÅ¬Ø impacts the fixed-point of the value function we converge to and c¬Øc¬Ø impacts the speed of convergence. When œÅ¬Ø=‚àûœÅ¬Ø=‚àû (untruncated), we converge to the value function of the target policy VœÄVœÄ; when œÅ¬ØœÅ¬Ø is close to 0, we evaluate the value function of the behavior policy VŒºVŒº; when in-between, we evaluate a policy between œÄœÄ and ŒºŒº.

The value function parameter is therefore updated in the direction of:

ŒîŒ∏=(vt‚àíVŒ∏(st))‚àáŒ∏VŒ∏(st)ŒîŒ∏=(vt‚àíVŒ∏(st))‚àáŒ∏VŒ∏(st)

The policy parameter œïœï is updated through policy gradient,

Œîœï=œÅt‚àáœïlogœÄœï(at|st)(rt+Œ≥vt+1‚àíVŒ∏(st))+‚àáœïH(œÄœï)=œÅt‚àáœïlogœÄœï(at|st)(rt+Œ≥vt+1‚àíVŒ∏(st))‚àí‚àáœï‚àëaœÄœï(a|st)logœÄœï(a|st)Œîœï=œÅt‚àáœïlog‚Å°œÄœï(at|st)(rt+Œ≥vt+1‚àíVŒ∏(st))+‚àáœïH(œÄœï)=œÅt‚àáœïlog‚Å°œÄœï(at|st)(rt+Œ≥vt+1‚àíVŒ∏(st))‚àí‚àáœï‚àëaœÄœï(a|st)log‚Å°œÄœï(a|st)

where rt+Œ≥vt+1rt+Œ≥vt+1 is the estimated Q value, from which a state-dependent baseline VŒ∏(st)VŒ∏(st) is subtracted. H(œÄœï)H(œÄœï) is an entropy bonus to encourage exploration.

In the experiments, IMPALA is used to train one agent over multiple tasks. Two different model architectures are involved, a shallow model (left) and a deep residual model (right).

Quick Summary

After reading through all the algorithms above, I list a few building blocks or principles that seem to be common among them:

  • Try to reduce the variance and keep the bias unchanged to stabilize learning.
  • Off-policy gives us better exploration and helps us use data samples more efficiently.
  • Experience replay (training data sampled from a replay memory buffer);
  • Target network that is either frozen periodically or updated slower than the actively learned policy network;
  • Batch normalization;
  • Entropy-regularized reward;
  • The critic and actor can share lower layer parameters of the network and two output heads for policy and value functions.
  • It is possible to learn with deterministic policy rather than stochastic one.
  • Put constraint on the divergence between policy updates.
  • New optimization methods (such as K-FAC).
  • Entropy maximization of the policy helps encourage exploration.
  • Try not to overestimate the value function.
  • Think twice whether the policy and value network should share parameters.
  • TBA more.
